newsitem.title: UK: High-yielder bonds come out on top in week - Salomon.
newsitem.headline: High-yielder bonds come out on top in week - Salomon.

text.p: Italian bonds were pipped at the post by Spanish bonds which took first place in the Salomon Brothers world government bond index for the week ended November 14, Salomon Brothers said on Friday.

Spanish consumer price data on Thursday rose 3.5 percent for October bringing Spain ever closer to the criteria needed to participate in the start of European Economic and Monetary Union, scheduled for 1999.
In Italy, the lower house of parliament has now approved the main body of the 1997 budget raising the prospects of Italy's re-entry to Europe's exchange rate mechanism, analysts said.
The European high yielders outstripped other government bond markets coming in more than 0.30 percentage points higher than British gilts, which made the third highest gains of the week.
Spanish Bonos returned a total of 1.17 percent in pesetas and 1.23 percent in dollars, while Italian BTPs gained 1.15 percent in lira terms and 1.14 percent in dollars.
British gilts made gains of 0.84 percent in sterling and 1.86 percent in dollars.
U.S. Treasuries rose 0.55 percent, beating core European bonds, while Japanese governement bonds (JGBs) lost money.
JGBs made a loss of 0.14 percent in local currency terms and a gain of 0.22 percent in dollars.
German Bunds recorded gains of 0.44 percent in marks and 0.34 percent in dollars, while French bonds returned 0.29 percent in local currecy terms and 0.24 percent in dollar terms.
Overall, the index rose 0.45 percent in local currency terms, a rise of 0.56 percent in dollars.

Salomon's bond index is calculated using all government bonds with over one year to maturity, weighted for market capitalisation. Only bonds freely available to institutional investors and with a certain minimum amount outstanding are included. Returns take account of price moves and accrued interest.
